revision_history.draft:
Steam rises slow
off the mug where you pressed your thumb

the way only children press—
a dent, a question

the kitchen light makes everything
the color of weak tea

water running in the sink
and under my fingers cold

that sound again—the faucet's particular
cough, like it coughs when no one is listening—

I put my face close to the glass
steam thins your outline

your coffee cup a hand held up
to block the sun from the table

the radio on low
something almost classical
a cello section I don't recognize

my teeth cold against each other
the way you clench them when thinking hard

you turned and said something
but my mouth is dry now, years here

I hold the mug and it has cooled
into a shape like your absence—
a shape I keep finding

breath on glass, breath off coffee,
same vapor, different seconds

dawn in the kitchen
nothing I can set down and say finished

just the sound of water
and my breathing beside it
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The closing four lines have genuine structural power:

> just the sound of water / and my breathing beside it

That line break between "water" and "my breathing" is doing real work — it enacts the separation, the inability to fold those sounds together into a single memory. The poem earns its ending there.

> Same vapor, different seconds

This line has compressed philosophical weight without reaching for abstraction. It stays in the subject: water vapor behaving physically but carrying temporal meaning. That's the kind of observation only this poem could make about this scene.

The physical detail of steam thinning a person's outline on glass — that's precise and strange enough to anchor the whole piece inside one domestic image rather than drifting into summary.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / self-conscious emotional restraint (lines 13-16):**
> I put my face close to the glass / steam thins your outline
> 
> your coffee cup a hand held up / to block the sun from the table
>
> the radio on low / something almost classical / a cello section I don't recognize

The first two lines are strong — physical, specific, earned. The third line collapses into vagueness: "something almost classical" is a dead metaphor for vague memory. "A cello section I don't recognize" is closer but still soft; what did you actually hear? What piece? The specificity isn't precise enough to feel like discovery.

**Cliché / near-cliché (throughout):**
- "Steam rises slow" — this is decorative, not observed.
- "the way only children press— / a dent, a question" — the personification of the dent into a question reads as a gesture toward profundity rather than something noticed. Direction: cut or replace with what actually happened in that moment of pressing and releasing.
- "my mouth is dry now, years here" — this tells us about nostalgia instead of staying inside sensation. What does a dry mouth feel like physically? The poem earns the right to name "years" only if it has built enough physical pressure first.

**Syntactic slack (line 10):**
> that sound again—the faucet's particular / cough, like it coughs when no one is listening—

The parenthetical structure flattens what could be an interesting sonic image. Direction: make the comparison its own line or phrase so it doesn't diffuse into the sentence.

**Repetition without escalation (line 23):**
> Same vapor, different seconds

This restates the closing idea without deepening it. The poem's final move should push further — this one retreats slightly into vagueness ("different seconds").

### Direction

The draft has found its shape in the last eight lines. Revise outward from there: sharpen the physical details that earn the emotional weight, and trust the

revision_history.draft:
Steam rises slow
off the mug where you pressed your thumb

the way only children press—
a dent, a question

the kitchen light makes everything
the color of weak tea

water running in the sink
and under my fingers cold

that sound again—the faucet's particular
cough, like it coughs when no one is listening—

I put my face close to the glass.
Steam thins your outline,
your coffee cup a hand held up
to block the sun from the table

the radio says something almost Stravinsky now—
a muted cello section I can't name whole,

just the second violins under everything else,
that dark entry behind the piano.

My teeth clench, that way you do when thinking hard.
You turned and said *more coffee* but meant
the mug itself, still warm,
still the shape of where your hand was.

Cold water on my fingertips—
a small percussion section I keep repeating
with just one knuckle. The kitchen
holds its ordinary sounds

and I hold the mug and it has cooled
into a shape like your absence—
not grief, not yet, but the particular dent
your thumb made, that question,

that dent.

Breath on glass,
a fog I smear with my palm until nothing's clear.
Breath off coffee,
vapor white, almost angry,
rising thin as an accent

I can't take back.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The closing eight lines are the strongest writing in this draft, and they're doing what the brief asked for:

> **My teeth clench, that way you do when thinking hard.** — The specificity of the bodily gesture earns its place; it doesn't name "thinking hard," it *is* the clenching.
>
> **the radio says something almost Stravinsky now— / a muted cello section I can't name whole, / just the second violins under everything else, / that dark entry behind the piano.** — The attention to what's actually audible in a domestic background is precise and strange. The reader feels the half-listening.
>
> **I put my face close to the glass. / Steam thins your outline,** — That line break between "glass" and "Steam thins" is doing real structural work: the steam literally erases the person before the speaker's eyes, and the break enacts that disappearance on the page.
>
> **a small percussion section I keep repeating / with just one knuckle.** — The final image of a single finger creating sound has quiet authority; it earns its place through physical specificity.

The poem is most alive when it stays inside sensory memory without naming what those memories *mean*.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché and near-cliché (throughout):**

- **"Steam rises slow" / "off the mug where you pressed your thumb"** — These are decorative, not observed. The draft revises this to something sharper ("slow off"), but it's still generic. Direction: cut or replace with what actually happened in that moment of pressing and releasing.
- **"the way only children press— / a dent, a question"** — Personifying the dent into a question reads as a gesture toward profundity rather than something noticed. The revision tightens this but doesn't fully resolve it; "a dent, that question" is closer to what's alive without the abstraction.
- **"water running in the sink / and under my fingers cold"** — This is fine. Direction: build outward from here with similar physical attention.

**Syntactic slack (line 10):**

> *that sound again—the faucet's particular / cough, like it coughs when no one is listening—*

The parenthetical structure flattens what could be an interesting sonic image. Direction: make the comparison its own line or phrase so it doesn't diffuse into the sentence.

**Repetition without escalation (line 23):**

> **Same vapor, different seconds**

This restates the closing idea without deepening it. The poem's final move should push further — this one retreats slightly into vagueness ("different seconds").

**Structural weakness: lines 17–24**

final_poem:
Steam rises slow
off the mug where you pressed your thumb

the way only children press—
a dent, a question

Cold water on my fingertips.
I keep tapping with one knuckle,
light percussion, a small
percussion section no one calls.

The kitchen light makes everything
the color of weak tea. Water running
in the sink and under my fingers cold,

and under them, the particular
cough of the faucet—like it's saying something
to the tile while nobody watches.

I put my face close to the glass.
Steam thins your outline,
your coffee cup a hand held up
to block the sun from the table

The radio says almost Stravinsky now:
a muted cello section I can't name whole,
just the second violins under everything else—
that dark entry behind the piano.

My teeth clench. You turned and said *more coffee* but meant
the mug itself, still warm,
still the shape of where your hand was.

That dent stays in the cup now,
that question your thumb asked of it.
Steam on glass—a fog I smear with my palm until nothing's clear,

then let return: each breath a new
atmosphere. Vapor white, almost angry,
rising thin as an accent
I can't take back.

The mug is nearly cold. It sits
on the table like your chair when you leave early—
a shape the room holds wrong, a dent
your absence makes before it has a name.

That's not it. The glass lets through
the first light, thin as a blade,
and I can see the countertop again,
its ordinary surface, its ordinary
stain. My thumb pressed deep. That's all.
The faucet still coughs. Cold water still runs.
I hold the mug and it is only
metal and my hand and the dent
your absence made before it had a name.

I will keep drinking from this cup.
